elements.content: Metal-center-driven spontaneous resolution of a pair of chiral doubly interpenetrated metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Ni3(ptd)6]·15.5H2O (1), which was synthesized from achiral precursors [ptd = 3-(pyridin-3-yl)-1,2,4-triazine-5,6-diol], shows vertical interpenetrated 2D → 3D frameworks with 1D channels. Interestingly, proceeding with solvothermal recrystallization in methanol, 1, with a high-symmetry tetragonal I4 space group, gives another tilted interpenetrated MOF of [Ni3(ptd)6]·10H2O·3.5MeOH (2), with low-symmetry monoclinic C2 space group. Accompanied with the structure transformation, a red shift in circular dichroism (CD) spectrum and a magnetic response (weak ferromagnetic interactions in 1 to weak antiferromagnetic interactions in 2) can be observed. Strikingly, 1 and 2 feature heterogeneous catalytic activities for the Knoevenagel reaction.
elements.clean_text: Metal-center-driven spontaneous resolution of a pair of chiral doubly interpenetrated metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), [Ni3(ptd)6]⋅15.5H2O (1), which was synthesized from achiral precursors [ptd = 3-(pyridin-3-yl)-1,2,4-triazine-5,6-diol], shows vertical interpenetrated 2D → 3D frameworks with 1D channels. Interestingly, proceeding with solvothermal recrystallization in methanol, 1, with a high-symmetry tetragonal I4 space group, gives another tilted interpenetrated MOF of [Ni3(ptd)6]⋅10H2O⋅3.5MeOH (2), with low-symmetry monoclinic C2 space group. Accompanied with the structure transformation, a red shift in circular dichroism (CD) spectrum and a magnetic response (weak ferromagnetic interactions in 1 to weak antiferromagnetic interactions in 2) can be observed. Strikingly, 1 and 2 feature heterogeneous catalytic activities for the Knoevenagel reaction.

elements.content: A pair of chiral doubly interpenetrated metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) was synthesized from achiral precursors by metal-center-driven spontaneous resolution. When 1 was solvothermal recrystallized in methanol, another tilted interpenetrated MOF 2 was obtained. Accompanied with the structure transformation, a red shift in the circular dichroism (CD) spectrum and a magnetic response can be observed. The MOFs 1 and 2 were employed as heterogeneous catalysts for the Knoevenagel reaction.
elements.clean_text: A pair of chiral doubly interpenetrated metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) was synthesized from achiral precursors by metal-center-driven spontaneous resolution. When 1 was solvothermal recrystallized in methanol, another tilted interpenetrated MOF 2 was obtained. Accompanied with the structure transformation, a red shift in the circular dichroism (CD) spectrum and a magnetic response can be observed. The MOFs 1 and 2 were employed as heterogeneous catalysts for the Knoevenagel reaction.

elements.content: Chirality possesses a distinguished place in nature and plays an important role in biological and material sciences. Recently, design and synthesis of chiral metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has become a topic of keen interest because of their remarkable potential applications in the area of asymmetric catalysis, enantioselective synthesis and separation, magnetism, nonlinear optical materials, and chiral recognition. Generally, there are two prime methodologies to construct chiral MOFs: (a) The usage of a chiral ligand, which can introduce their inherent chirality into the overall framework via a “chirality conservation” process (chirality from chiral carbon atoms, axial chirality, helical structure or planar chirality of chiral organic molecules). (b) The uses of chiral auxiliaries such as chiral solvent, catalyst, or template lead to a particular handedness. However, the two methodologies suffer from the high costs of enantiopure organic linkers and chiral auxiliaries.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chirality possesses a distinguished place in nature and plays an important role in biological and material sciences. Recently, design and synthesis of chiral metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has become a topic of keen interest because of their remarkable potential applications in the area of asymmetric catalysis, enantioselective synthesis and separation, magnetism, nonlinear optical materials, and chiral recognition. Generally, there are two prime methodologies to construct chiral MOFs: (a) The usage of a chiral ligand, which can introduce their inherent chirality into the overall framework via a "chirality conservation" process (chirality from chiral carbon atoms, axial chirality, helical structure or planar chirality of chiral organic molecules). (b) The uses of chiral auxiliaries such as chiral solvent, catalyst, or template lead to a particular handedness. However, the two methodologies suffer from the high costs of enantiopure organic linkers and chiral auxiliaries.

elements.content: Moreover, chiral MOFs can also be constructed by using achiral precursors with spontaneous resolution without using any chiral auxiliaries. The spontaneous resolution of chiral MOFs from achiral precursors usually results in conglomerates, i.e., a mixture of homochiral crystals having opposite handedness. However, the generation of homochirality from achiral precursors is still unpredictable. Various factors such as coordination around the metal center, selection of the ligands, and host–guest interactions and stacking interactions can maneuver the formation of chiral MOFs from achiral building blocks. At the same time, crystallization process is inclined to centrosymmetry. The homochiral crystallization of MOFs from achiral building blocks still remains a scantily explored area. Self-assembly of chiral MOFs consisting of achiral building blocks by means of spontaneous resolution is an interesting phenomenon.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, chiral MOFs can also be constructed by using achiral precursors with spontaneous resolution without using any chiral auxiliaries. The spontaneous resolution of chiral MOFs from achiral precursors usually results in conglomerates, i.e., a mixture of homochiral crystals having opposite handedness. However, the generation of homochirality from achiral precursors is still unpredictable. Various factors such as coordination around the metal center, selection of the ligands, and host-guest interactions and stacking interactions can maneuver the formation of chiral MOFs from achiral building blocks. At the same time, crystallization process is inclined to centrosymmetry. The homochiral crystallization of MOFs from achiral building blocks still remains a scantily explored area. Self-assembly of chiral MOFs consisting of achiral building blocks by means of spontaneous resolution is an interesting phenomenon.

elements.content: The Knoevenagel condensation of aldehydes with active methylene compounds is one of the most useful C–C bond forming reactions having wide applications for the synthesis of fine chemicals. This condensation is generally catalyzed by bases or Lewis acids and widely studied in homogeneous systems. However, the separation and disposal of homogeneous catalysts are not easy tasks. To overcome this limitation, heterogeneous catalysts have been developed. Some reports have employed MOFs as promising heterogeneous catalysts. Thus, the development of suitable MOF-based catalysts for this reaction is a topic of great interest.
elements.clean_text: The Knoevenagel condensation of aldehydes with active methylene compounds is one of the most useful C-C bond forming reactions having wide applications for the synthesis of fine chemicals. This condensation is generally catalyzed by bases or Lewis acids and widely studied in homogeneous systems. However, the separation and disposal of homogeneous catalysts are not easy tasks. To overcome this limitation, heterogeneous catalysts have been developed. Some reports have employed MOFs as promising heterogeneous catalysts. Thus, the development of suitable MOF-based catalysts for this reaction is a topic of great interest.

elements.content: Herein, we selected achiral precursor ptd = 3-(pyridin-3-yl)-1,2,4-triazine-5,6-diol, by metal-center-driven spontaneous resolution, synthesized a pair of chiral doubly interpenetrated metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Ni3(ptd)6]·15.5H2O (1, including Λ-1 and Δ-1), and shown vertical interpenetrated 2D → 3D frameworks with 1D channels. When proceeding with solvothermal recrystallization in methanol, 1 gives another complex of 2 as [Ni3(ptd)6]·10H2O·3.5MeOH, accompanied by an interesting structure transformation. Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in different space groups (high-symmetry tetragonal I4 for 1, and low-symmetry monoclinic C2 for 2). The structure transformation from 1 to 2 leads to the change of corresponding magnetic and circular dichroism spectra. Furthermore, 1 and 2 exhibit heterogeneous catalytic performance for Knoevenagel condensation at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we selected achiral precursor ptd = 3-(pyridin-3-yl)-1,2,4-triazine-5,6-diol, by metal-center-driven spontaneous resolution, synthesized a pair of chiral doubly interpenetrated metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), [Ni3(ptd)6]⋅15.5H2O (1, including Λ-1 and Δ-1), and shown vertical interpenetrated 2D → 3D frameworks with 1D channels. When proceeding with solvothermal recrystallization in methanol, 1 gives another complex of 2 as [Ni3(ptd)6]⋅10H2O⋅3.5MeOH, accompanied by an interesting structure transformation. Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in different space groups (high-symmetry tetragonal I4 for 1, and low-symmetry monoclinic C2 for 2). The structure transformation from 1 to 2 leads to the change of corresponding magnetic and circular dichroism spectra. Furthermore, 1 and 2 exhibit heterogeneous catalytic performance for Knoevenagel condensation at room temperature.

elements.content: The ligand of ptd was prepared according to a literature procedure. All reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a model 2400 II PerkinElmer elemental analyzer. The magnetic susceptibility measurements of the polycrystalline samples were measured over the temperature range of 2–300 K with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer using an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the region 400–4000 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) intensities were measured on a Rigaku D/max diffractometer (Cu–Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å). The single-crystalline powder samples were prepared by crushing the crystals and scanned from 3 to 60° with a step of 5° min–1. The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra were recorded on a Jasco J-750 spectropolarimeter using KBr pellets. TG-DTA tests were performed on a PerkinElmer thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The catalytic products were measured by GCMS­(Agilent).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and Physical Measurements

The ligand of ptd was prepared according to a literature procedure. All reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a model 2400 II PerkinElmer elemental analyzer. The magnetic susceptibility measurements of the polycrystalline samples were measured over the temperature range of 2-300 K with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer using an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the region 400-4000 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) intensities were measured on a Rigaku D/max diffractometer (Cu-Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å). The single-crystalline powder samples were prepared by crushing the crystals and scanned from 3 to 60° with a step of 5° min-1. The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra were recorded on a Jasco J-750 spectropolarimeter using KBr pellets. TG-DTA tests were performed on a PerkinElmer thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The catalytic products were measured by GCMS(Agilent).

elements.content: A mixture containing ptd (0.3 mmol), NiSO4·5H2O (0.5 mmol), and water (15 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, and 0.22 mL concentration 0.01 mol/L NaOH solution (pH = 10.1) was added and stirred for 30 min then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL), which was heated at 160 °C for 3 days and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h. Blue needle crystals of 1 were obtained, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 17% (based on NiII). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd: C,36.25; H, 3.83; N, 21.14. Found: C: 37.04; H: 3.21; N: 22.91. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3450(s), 1634(s), 1553(s), 1458­(m), 1460­(m), 1422­(m), 1364­(m), 1309(s), 1191­(m), 1097­(w), 1102­(w), 1054­(w), 1034­(w), 984­(m), 819­(w), 738­(m), 718­(m), 662(s), 612(s). The enantiomorphs (Λ-1 and Δ-1) with similar crystal shapes could be separated from the resulting mixed crystalline products of 1, on the basis of their slightly different cell determination (Table S1).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[Ni3(ptd)6]⋅15.5H2O (1, Including Λ-1 and Δ-1)

A mixture containing ptd (0.3 mmol), NiSO4⋅5H2O (0.5 mmol), and water (15 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, and 0.22 mL concentration 0.01 mol/L NaOH solution (pH = 10.1) was added and stirred for 30 min then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL), which was heated at 160 °C for 3 days and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h. Blue needle crystals of 1 were obtained, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 17% (based on NiII). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd: C,36.25; H, 3.83; N, 21.14. Found: C: 37.04; H: 3.21; N: 22.91. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3450(s), 1634(s), 1553(s), 1458(m), 1460(m), 1422(m), 1364(m), 1309(s), 1191(m), 1097(w), 1102(w), 1054(w), 1034(w), 984(m), 819(w), 738(m), 718(m), 662(s), 612(s). The enantiomorphs (Λ-1 and Δ-1) with similar crystal shapes could be separated from the resulting mixed crystalline products of 1, on the basis of their slightly different cell determination (Table S1).

elements.content: As-synthesized 1 in methanol (10 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) was stirred in a Teflon-lined autoclave and placed under autogenous pressure at 130 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 2 were obtained in yields of about 19% (based on 1). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd: C, 38.89; H, 4.03; N, 21.14. Found: C, 39.15; H, 4.22; N, 21.94. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3445(s), 1632(s), 1551(s), 1460­(m), 1460­(m), 1421­(m), 1364­(m), 1309(s), 1191­(m), 1096­(w), 1102­(w), 1052­(w), 1034­(w), 984­(m), 819­(w), 738­(m), 720­(m), 662(s), 616(s).
elements.clean_text:
[Ni3(ptd)6]⋅10H2O⋅3.5MeOH (2, Including Λ-2 and Δ-2)

As-synthesized 1 in methanol (10 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) was stirred in a Teflon-lined autoclave and placed under autogenous pressure at 130 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 2 were obtained in yields of about 19% (based on 1). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd: C, 38.89; H, 4.03; N, 21.14. Found: C, 39.15; H, 4.22; N, 21.94. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3445(s), 1632(s), 1551(s), 1460(m), 1460(m), 1421(m), 1364(m), 1309(s), 1191(m), 1096(w), 1102(w), 1052(w), 1034(w), 984(m), 819(w), 738(m), 720(m), 662(s), 616(s).

elements.content: Through single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, the single crystal structure of Λ-2 was obtained. Unfortunately, the single crystal structure of enantiomorph Δ-2 was not obtained after many attempts. We also tried recrystallization in methanol at room temperature. However, the process was so slow that the ultimate products were a mix crystalline samples 1 and 2 ().
elements.clean_text: Through single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, the single crystal structure of Λ-2 was obtained. Unfortunately, the single crystal structure of enantiomorph Δ-2 was not obtained after many attempts. We also tried recrystallization in methanol at room temperature. However, the process was so slow that the ultimate products were a mix crystalline samples 1 and 2 ().

elements.content: Single crystals with suitable dimensions were chosen under an optical microscope and mounted on a glass fiber for data collection. All reflection data were collected on an Agilent Supernova diffractometer (Mo, λ= 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The data integration and reduction were processed using CrysAlisPro software. The structures were solved by direct methods using ShelXS and refined using a full-matrix least-squares technique within ShelXL2014 and OLEX.2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically until convergence is reached. Hydrogen atoms attached to the organic moieties present in all compounds are either located from the difference Fourier map or stereochemically fixed. Guest molecules in Λ-1, Δ-1, and Λ-2 are significantly disordered and could not be modeled properly due to the lack of well define atomic positions, and PLATON/SQUEEZE was employed to remove these electron densities. The Squeeze procedure is a widely used and accepted method that corrects diffraction data for structures affected by the presence of heavily disordered solvent. However, the use of Squeeze does not impact the framework atoms. Topological analysis of compound was performed by using ToposPro software. Summary of crystallographic data and details of data collection for Λ-1, Δ-1, and Λ-2 are given in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles for Λ-1, Δ-1, and Λ-2 are collected in Table S2. The continuous shape measures calculation results (CShMs) for Λ-1, Δ-1, and Λ-2 using Shape 2.1 are provided in Table S3. Crystallographic data for the structural analyses has been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC reference numbers: 1871554–1871556).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystals with suitable dimensions were chosen under an optical microscope and mounted on a glass fiber for data collection. All reflection data were collected on an Agilent Supernova diffractometer (Mo, λ= 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The data integration and reduction were processed using CrysAlisPro software. The structures were solved by direct methods using ShelXS and refined using a full-matrix least-squares technique within ShelXL2014 and OLEX.2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically until convergence is reached. Hydrogen atoms attached to the organic moieties present in all compounds are either located from the difference Fourier map or stereochemically fixed. Guest molecules in Λ-1, Δ-1, and Λ-2 are significantly disordered and could not be modeled properly due to the lack of well define atomic positions, and PLATON/SQUEEZE was employed to remove these electron densities. The Squeeze procedure is a widely used and accepted method that corrects diffraction data for structures affected by the presence of heavily disordered solvent. However, the use of Squeeze does not impact the framework atoms. Topological analysis of compound was performed by using ToposPro software. Summary of crystallographic data and details of data collection for Λ-1, Δ-1, and Λ-2 are given in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles for Λ-1, Δ-1, and Λ-2 are collected in Table S2. The continuous shape measures calculation results (CShMs) for Λ-1, Δ-1, and Λ-2 using Shape 2.1 are provided in Table S3. Crystallographic data for the structural analyses has been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC reference numbers: 1871554-1871556).

elements.content: During crystallization, spontaneous resolution occurs, and the single crystals of both enantiomorphs of 1 (Λ-1 and Δ-1) have been randomly selected. The X-ray crystallographic studies revealed that Λ-1 and Δ-1 are enantiomorphs, and henceforth, the structure of Λ-1 is discussed in detail. Crystals Λ-1 crystallized in the tetragonal system with chiral space group I4. The asymmetric unit of Λ-1 contains one and half NiII cation, Ni2 occupying a special position and C4 symmetry, three ptd anions, and disordered guest water molecules. Each crystallographically independent NiII ion is coordinated by four O atoms from two ptd and two pyridine N atoms from another two ptd ligands, forming a [NiO4N2] distorted octahedral configuration (). The bond lengths are Ni–N = 2.060(8)–2.076(7) Å, Ni–O = 2.027(5)–2.130(6) Å. The pyridine N atom and chelated O atom of triazine-diol from different ptd moieties in Λ and Δ coordination constitute octahedral configurations around the metal centers in Λ-1 and Δ-1 (). Each NiII atom is connected to four other NiII atoms by means of linear ptd ligand, yielding a four-connected node, and further form two-dimensional (2D) layer architecture (a and S1). These four connected uninodal topologies described by a short Schläfli symbol of (326272). Interestingly, the 2D layer architecture is further involved in perpendicular interpenetration (both parallel to the c-axis) to realize a 2D → 3D MOF (b–d). The distance of adjacent NiII ions was depicted in Figure S2a, in which the shortest distance is 5.791 Å. The 3D MOF with 1D channels appears to have large open windows (of the size of 14.4946(4) × 14.4946(5) Å), while the 2D layers are interpenetrated to each other, resulting in much smaller open channels of 7.57 Å × 7.57 Å (Figures S3). As estimated by PLATON program, the total effective free volume of Λ-1 and Δ-1 with removal of solvent molecules is 37.4% and 39.1%, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

Structure of [Ni3(ptd)6]⋅15.5H2O (1)

During crystallization, spontaneous resolution occurs, and the single crystals of both enantiomorphs of 1 (Λ-1 and Δ-1) have been randomly selected. The X-ray crystallographic studies revealed that Λ-1 and Δ-1 are enantiomorphs, and henceforth, the structure of Λ-1 is discussed in detail. Crystals Λ-1 crystallized in the tetragonal system with chiral space group I4. The asymmetric unit of Λ-1 contains one and half NiII cation, Ni2 occupying a special position and C4 symmetry, three ptd anions, and disordered guest water molecules. Each crystallographically independent NiII ion is coordinated by four O atoms from two ptd and two pyridine N atoms from another two ptd ligands, forming a [NiO4N2] distorted octahedral configuration (). The bond lengths are Ni-N = 2.060(8)-2.076(7) Å, Ni-O = 2.027(5)-2.130(6) Å. The pyridine N atom and chelated O atom of triazine-diol from different ptd moieties in Λ and Δ coordination constitute octahedral configurations around the metal centers in Λ-1 and Δ-1 (). Each NiII atom is connected to four other NiII atoms by means of linear ptd ligand, yielding a four-connected node, and further form two-dimensional (2D) layer architecture (a and S1). These four connected uninodal topologies described by a short Schläfli symbol of (326272). Interestingly, the 2D layer architecture is further involved in perpendicular interpenetration (both parallel to the c-axis) to realize a 2D → 3D MOF (b-d). The distance of adjacent NiII ions was depicted in Figure S2a, in which the shortest distance is 5.791 Å. The 3D MOF with 1D channels appears to have large open windows (of the size of 14.4946(4) × 14.4946(5) Å), while the 2D layers are interpenetrated to each other, resulting in much smaller open channels of 7.57 Å × 7.57 Å (Figures S3). As estimated by PLATON program, the total effective free volume of Λ-1 and Δ-1 with removal of solvent molecules is 37.4% and 39.1%, respectively.

elements.content: Absolute configuration and coordination environment of NiII center in enantiomorphs Λ-1 and Δ-1 (H atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  Absolute configuration and coordination environment of NiII center in enantiomorphs Λ-1 and Δ-1 (H atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: (a) Two-dimensional topological depiction of Λ-1; (b) two interpenetrated frameworks are depicted in blue and green colors; (c) perpendicular interspersed three-dimensional structure of Λ-1 running along the c-axis; (d) 2D → 3D perpendicular doubly interpenetration topology of Λ-1.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Two-dimensional topological depiction of Λ-1; (b) two interpenetrated frameworks are depicted in blue and green colors; (c) perpendicular interspersed three-dimensional structure of Λ-1 running along the c-axis; (d) 2D → 3D perpendicular doubly interpenetration topology of Λ-1.

elements.content: Crystals Λ-2 crystallized in the monoclinic system with chiral space group C 2. The asymmetric unit of Λ-2 contains two and two half NiII cations, Ni2 and Ni4 occupying special position and C2 symmetry, six PTD anions, and disordered guest water and methanol molecules (Figures S4). The coordination environment of NiII ion is the same as Λ-1, forming a [NiO4N2] distorted octahedral configuration. Adjacent NiII ions are bridged by ptd to form a 2D layer architecture. Due to the different symmetry of the crystals, the 2D layer architecture is further involved in slant interpenetration (both parallel to the b-axis) to realize a 2D → 3D MOF, and they titled from each other with a dihedral angle of 86° (). The distance of adjacent NiII ions was depicted in Figure S2c, in which the shortest distance is 5.772 Å. Along the b-axis, similar to 1D channels of Λ-1, the sizes of open channels of Λ-2 are 7.50 Å × 7.65 Å (Figure S5). As estimated by PLATON program, the total effective free volume of Λ-2 with removal of solvent molecules is 37.9%.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Ni3(ptd)6]⋅10H2O⋅3.5MeOH (Λ-2)

Crystals Λ-2 crystallized in the monoclinic system with chiral space group  C  2. The asymmetric unit of Λ-2 contains two and two half NiII cations, Ni2 and Ni4 occupying special position and C2 symmetry, six PTD anions, and disordered guest water and methanol molecules (Figures S4). The coordination environment of NiII ion is the same as Λ-1, forming a [NiO4N2] distorted octahedral configuration. Adjacent NiII ions are bridged by ptd to form a 2D layer architecture. Due to the different symmetry of the crystals, the 2D layer architecture is further involved in slant interpenetration (both parallel to the b-axis) to realize a 2D → 3D MOF, and they titled from each other with a dihedral angle of 86° (). The distance of adjacent NiII ions was depicted in Figure S2c, in which the shortest distance is 5.772 Å. Along the b-axis, similar to 1D channels of Λ-1, the sizes of open channels of Λ-2 are 7.50 Å × 7.65 Å (Figure S5). As estimated by PLATON program, the total effective free volume of Λ-2 with removal of solvent molecules is 37.9%.

elements.content: (a) Slant doubly interspersed 3D structure of Λ-2 running along the b-axis; (b) 2D → 3D slant doubly interpenetration topology of Λ-2.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Slant doubly interspersed 3D structure of Λ-2 running along the b-axis; (b) 2D → 3D slant doubly interpenetration topology of Λ-2.

elements.content: Analysis of the structures revealed that water molecules are located in 1D channels along the c-axis for 1, while MeOH + H2O is trapped in wider cavities along the b-axis for 2. Thus, the size and shape of the guests and their internal interactions might be of significant importance to the generation of the interpenetrated structures of both complexes. The significant structural change is that dihedral angle of doubly interpenetrated layers is exactly perpendicularly deformed into titled. The subtle change is the NiII coordination environment. The deviation from the ideal octahedron of O h symmetry can be determined by the CShM values (Table S3). Although all CShM values are less than 1, CShM value of Λ-2 is significantly larger/smaller than that of 1 (Λ-1 and Δ-1). Such small changes may lead to changes in the structure of the skeleton, circular dichroism, and magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: Analysis of the structures revealed that water molecules are located in 1D channels along the c-axis for 1, while MeOH + H2O is trapped in wider cavities along the b-axis for 2. Thus, the size and shape of the guests and their internal interactions might be of significant importance to the generation of the interpenetrated structures of both complexes. The significant structural change is that dihedral angle of doubly interpenetrated layers is exactly perpendicularly deformed into titled. The subtle change is the NiII coordination environment. The deviation from the ideal octahedron of O  h  symmetry can be determined by the CShM values (Table S3). Although all CShM values are less than 1, CShM value of Λ-2 is significantly larger/smaller than that of 1 (Λ-1 and Δ-1). Such small changes may lead to changes in the structure of the skeleton, circular dichroism, and magnetic properties.

elements.content: At the vertical interpenetration of MOFs with 1D channels, guest molecules play a supporting role, and different guest molecules might cause structural transformations. So, recrystallization was tried in methanol. As-synthesized 1 (10 mg) was soaked in methanol solution at room temperature for 1–3 days; the PXRD experiments revealed this process, shown in . All the diffraction peaks for freshly prepared 1 were coinciding to the simulated patterns, showing good crystalline phase purity (Figure S6a). The differences in intensities may be due to the preferred orientation of the powder samples. When 1 was soaked in methanol solution for 1 day, the PXRD patterns are almost the same as those of 1; After 3 days, the PXRD patterns exhibited a decrease in intensity, and the positions of the peaks changed, suggesting that the frameworks of 1 were being gradually transformed. Some new Bragg reflection peaks were the same as those simulated from the single crystal structure determinations for Λ-2. Therefore, we believe that the structural change of 1 was affected by the methanol solvent. However, this process was slow and difficult to obtain testable single crystals. Thus, in order to obtain good crystalline phase purity, as-synthesized 1 in methanol (15 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) was recrystallized in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 130 °C for 3 days, and homogeneous crystalline products of 2 were obtained (Figure S6b).
elements.clean_text:
Structure Transformation in MeOH

At the vertical interpenetration of MOFs with 1D channels, guest molecules play a supporting role, and different guest molecules might cause structural transformations. So, recrystallization was tried in methanol. As-synthesized 1 (10 mg) was soaked in methanol solution at room temperature for 1-3 days; the PXRD experiments revealed this process, shown in . All the diffraction peaks for freshly prepared 1 were coinciding to the simulated patterns, showing good crystalline phase purity (Figure S6a). The differences in intensities may be due to the preferred orientation of the powder samples. When 1 was soaked in methanol solution for 1 day, the PXRD patterns are almost the same as those of 1; After 3 days, the PXRD patterns exhibited a decrease in intensity, and the positions of the peaks changed, suggesting that the frameworks of 1 were being gradually transformed. Some new Bragg reflection peaks were the same as those simulated from the single crystal structure determinations for Λ-2. Therefore, we believe that the structural change of 1 was affected by the methanol solvent. However, this process was slow and difficult to obtain testable single crystals. Thus, in order to obtain good crystalline phase purity, as-synthesized 1 in methanol (15 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) was recrystallized in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 130 °C for 3 days, and homogeneous crystalline products of 2 were obtained (Figure S6b).

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) profiles of 1 after soaking in MeOH for different time periods.
elements.clean_text: 4  Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) profiles of 1 after soaking in MeOH for different time periods.

elements.content: In comparing the structures of Λ-1 and Λ-2, we find both of them have similar structure frameworks. First, the ptd ligand has similar coordination modes. Second, Λ-1 and Λ-2 have the same topology. Third, both of them have similar 1D channels with large void space. These similarities prove this transformation successful. However, for Λ-1 the water molecules are located in 1D channels along the c-axis, while for Λ-2 the MeOH + H2O is trapped in wider cavities along the b-axis. Different guest molecules change the dihedral angles of those two sets of interpenetrated grids. The symmetry of the structure also changes from I4 in Λ-1 to C2 in Λ-2. This transformation may be solution-induced uptake or exchange of guest molecules, and results in symmetry transformation.
elements.clean_text: In comparing the structures of Λ-1 and Λ-2, we find both of them have similar structure frameworks. First, the ptd ligand has similar coordination modes. Second, Λ-1 and Λ-2 have the same topology. Third, both of them have similar 1D channels with large void space. These similarities prove this transformation successful. However, for Λ-1 the water molecules are located in 1D channels along the c-axis, while for Λ-2 the MeOH + H2O is trapped in wider cavities along the b-axis. Different guest molecules change the dihedral angles of those two sets of interpenetrated grids. The symmetry of the structure also changes from I4 in Λ-1 to C2 in Λ-2. This transformation may be solution-induced uptake or exchange of guest molecules, and results in symmetry transformation.

elements.content: As we know, the observation of chiral space groups may not fully guarantee that the crystal as an entry will be optically active since either racemic crystal twinning or lamellar epitaxy may happen. The chiral nature of the enantiomorphs Λ-1 and Δ-1 was further established by solid-state CD spectra. The spectrum for a single crystal of Δ-1 displays two positive peaks at 526 and 592 nm, while that for Λ-1 is approximately the mirror image of Δ-1 (a). After structural transformation, the CD signals of Λ-2 display two characteristic peaks, at 566 and 599 nm, respectively. The red shift from 526 nm in Λ-1 to 566 nm in Λ-2 may be due to the subtle change of octahedral field and affected by guest molecules on the MOF structure. Taking ten randomly picked single crystal samples of 1 with different sizes from the same batch, they have similar CD signals to those observed in Λ-1 or Δ-1. Among them, four of the samples have the same signals to Λ-1, while the others have similar spectra to Δ-1. Furthermore, no visible CD response can be observed for the bulky sample, indicating two enantiomers in nearly 1:1 ratio (b). Concurrence of the CD experiments and single-crystal studies confirms that 1 is a conglomerate consisting of enantiomorphs Λ-1 and Δ-1. For 2, as expected, a mixture of few randomly picked up crystals exhibits no CD signal (Figure S7b).
elements.clean_text:
CD Properties

As we know, the observation of chiral space groups may not fully guarantee that the crystal as an entry will be optically active since either racemic crystal twinning or lamellar epitaxy may happen. The chiral nature of the enantiomorphs Λ-1 and Δ-1 was further established by solid-state CD spectra. The spectrum for a single crystal of Δ-1 displays two positive peaks at 526 and 592 nm, while that for Λ-1 is approximately the mirror image of Δ-1 (a). After structural transformation, the CD signals of Λ-2 display two characteristic peaks, at 566 and 599 nm, respectively. The red shift from 526 nm in Λ-1 to 566 nm in Λ-2 may be due to the subtle change of octahedral field and affected by guest molecules on the MOF structure. Taking ten randomly picked single crystal samples of 1 with different sizes from the same batch, they have similar CD signals to those observed in Λ-1 or Δ-1. Among them, four of the samples have the same signals to Λ-1, while the others have similar spectra to Δ-1. Furthermore, no visible CD response can be observed for the bulky sample, indicating two enantiomers in nearly 1:1 ratio (b). Concurrence of the CD experiments and single-crystal studies confirms that 1 is a conglomerate consisting of enantiomorphs Λ-1 and Δ-1. For 2, as expected, a mixture of few randomly picked up crystals exhibits no CD signal (Figure S7b).

elements.content: (a) Solid-state CD spectra of Λ-1 (red line), Δ-1 (black line), and Λ-2 (blue line); (b) ten crystals picked up randomly, four are Λ-1 (red line) and the others are Δ-1 (blue line), and a mixture of few randomly picked up crystals exhibit no CD signals (green line).
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Solid-state CD spectra of Λ-1 (red line), Δ-1 (black line), and Λ-2 (blue line); (b) ten crystals picked up randomly, four are Λ-1 (red line) and the others are Δ-1 (blue line), and a mixture of few randomly picked up crystals exhibit no CD signals (green line).

elements.content: To test catalytic activity of Ni-MOF 1 and 2, we performed the Knoevenagel condensation by using them as the catalysts under methylbenzene conditions (). Experiments were carried out with different substituent positions aromatic aldehydes with malononitrile under the same catalytic conditions. The results indicate that both the catalysts could convert all benzaldehyde derivatives studied to the corresponding condensation product effectively (Figure S10). Remarkably, in the absence of catalyst, the products could not be obtained. Both MOFs 1 and 2 showed almost the same catalytic trend in which the maximum product yield is provided by p-nitrobenzaldehyde (94%/92%), while the lowest one (65%/68%) was obtained for o-nitrobenzaldehyde. The m-nitrobenzaldehyde gave 78% and 81% yield with respect to MOF 1 and 2 catalysts. The results show that the substituent group’s position on the benzaldehyde (size effect) has a significant influence on the catalytic yields. The similar catalytic activities of 1 and 2 may be caused by their similar flexible framework. Unfortunately, due to their flexible interpenetration framework, the crystallinity or phase purity of the catalyst after catalysis was difficult to maintain.
elements.clean_text:
Knoevenagel Condensation Reaction

To test catalytic activity of Ni-MOF 1 and 2, we performed the Knoevenagel condensation by using them as the catalysts under methylbenzene conditions (). Experiments were carried out with different substituent positions aromatic aldehydes with malononitrile under the same catalytic conditions. The results indicate that both the catalysts could convert all benzaldehyde derivatives studied to the corresponding condensation product effectively (Figure S10). Remarkably, in the absence of catalyst, the products could not be obtained. Both MOFs 1 and 2 showed almost the same catalytic trend in which the maximum product yield is provided by p-nitrobenzaldehyde (94%/92%), while the lowest one (65%/68%) was obtained for o-nitrobenzaldehyde. The m-nitrobenzaldehyde gave 78% and 81% yield with respect to MOF 1 and 2 catalysts. The results show that the substituent group's position on the benzaldehyde (size effect) has a significant influence on the catalytic yields. The similar catalytic activities of 1 and 2 may be caused by their similar flexible framework. Unfortunately, due to their flexible interpenetration framework, the crystallinity or phase purity of the catalyst after catalysis was difficult to maintain.

elements.content:
Yields of MOF <bold>1</bold>- and <bold>2</bold>-Catalyzed Knoevenagel Condensation of Aromatic Aldehydes<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref>

Reaction performed at room temperature under methylbenzene conditions (2 mL), 0.2 mmol aldehyde, 0.2 mmol malononitrile, 2 mol % catalyst, 24 h.

Yield of products were determined by GCMS.

On the basis of crystal structure and previous reports, a possible mechanism of the Knoevenagel reaction catalyzed by MOFs 1 and 2 is illustrated in . The nickel center (Lewis acid site) interacts with the carbonyl oxygen from the aldehyde, producing a polarization of this group and thus increasing the electrophilic character of the carbonylic carbon atom. This polarization favors the attack from the malononitrile. Simultaneously, the interaction of a cyano group of malononitrile with the Lewis acid enhances the deprotonation of malononitrile. Then, the carbonium anion reacts with the carbonyl group from the aldehyde (form C–C bond) to give an intermediate that undergoes rearrangement and dehydration to given the product.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of crystal structure and previous reports, a possible mechanism of the Knoevenagel reaction catalyzed by MOFs 1 and 2 is illustrated in . The nickel center (Lewis acid site) interacts with the carbonyl oxygen from the aldehyde, producing a polarization of this group and thus increasing the electrophilic character of the carbonylic carbon atom. This polarization favors the attack from the malononitrile. Simultaneously, the interaction of a cyano group of malononitrile with the Lewis acid enhances the deprotonation of malononitrile. Then, the carbonium anion reacts with the carbonyl group from the aldehyde (form C-C bond) to give an intermediate that undergoes rearrangement and dehydration to given the product.

elements.content: Proposed possible catalytic mechanism for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction catalyzed by MOFs 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: 6  Proposed possible catalytic mechanism for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction catalyzed by MOFs 1 and 2.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility measurements for 1 and 2 were carried out over the range of 2–300 K under an applied field of 1000 Oe (). The χM T value at 300 K (3.154 and 3.211 cm3·K·mol–1 for 1 and 2) is close to the spin-only value of 3.00 cm3·K·mol–1 of three isolated NiII ion (S = 1). As the temperature decreases, the χM T value of 1 increases gradually to a maximum value of 4.519 cm3·K·mol–1 at 21 K and then drops to reach 2.438 cm3·K·mol–1 at 2 K, while the χM T value of 2 decreases gradually to 1.658 cm3·K·mol–1 at 2 K. The reciprocal molar susceptibilities at 45–300 K follow the Curie–Weiss law of 1/χM = (T – Θ)/C where C = 3.29 and 3.22 cm3·K·mol–1 and Θ = 1.87 and −1.95 K for 1 and 2, respectively. The positive Θ in 1 and negative Θ in 2 suggest that there are weak but dominant ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic superexchange interactions between the NiII ions in 1 and 2, respectively. Taking the structural features of 1 and 2 into consideration, the observed ferromagnetic interaction in 1 may arise from the magnetic superexchange from orthogonal magnetic orbitals in perpendicular interpenetrated Ni-MOFs structure. When influenced by guest molecules, the dihedral angle of doubly interpenetrated layers is slightly deformed into tilted, which led to magnetic change from ferromagnetic interactions to antiferromagnetic interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Magnetic susceptibility measurements for 1 and 2 were carried out over the range of 2-300 K under an applied field of 1000 Oe (). The χM T value at 300 K (3.154 and 3.211 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 for 1 and 2) is close to the spin-only value of 3.00 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 of three isolated NiII ion (S = 1). As the temperature decreases, the χM T value of 1 increases gradually to a maximum value of 4.519 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 21 K and then drops to reach 2.438 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 2 K, while the χM T value of 2 decreases gradually to 1.658 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 2 K. The reciprocal molar susceptibilities at 45-300 K follow the Curie-Weiss law of 1/χM = (T - Θ)/C where C = 3.29 and 3.22 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 and Θ = 1.87 and -1.95 K for 1 and 2, respectively. The positive Θ in 1 and negative Θ in 2 suggest that there are weak but dominant ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic superexchange interactions between the NiII ions in 1 and 2, respectively. Taking the structural features of 1 and 2 into consideration, the observed ferromagnetic interaction in 1 may arise from the magnetic superexchange from orthogonal magnetic orbitals in perpendicular interpenetrated Ni-MOFs structure. When influenced by guest molecules, the dihedral angle of doubly interpenetrated layers is slightly deformed into tilted, which led to magnetic change from ferromagnetic interactions to antiferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility of 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: 7  Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility of 1 and 2.

elements.content: In summary, a pair of metal-center-driven spontaneous resolution doubly interpenetrated MOFs (Λ-1 and Δ-1) have been synthesized from achiral precursors and show vertical interpenetrated 2D → 3D frameworks with 1D channels. When proceeding with solvothermal recrystallization in methanol, 1 gives complex 2, accompanied by structure transformation, and shows tilted interpenetrated 2D → 3D frameworks. When induced by different guest molecules for subtle modification of the local environments of the NiII centers, the complexes of 1 and 2 crystallize in different space groups. As a result, structure transformation from 1 to 2 leads to the modification of their magnetic properties and circular dichroism spectra. Furthermore, 1 and 2 can be used as heterogeneous catalysts in the Knoevenagel condensation with high catalytic activities. Investigations on their potential use as catalysts for other reactions are in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a pair of metal-center-driven spontaneous resolution doubly interpenetrated MOFs (Λ-1 and Δ-1) have been synthesized from achiral precursors and show vertical interpenetrated 2D → 3D frameworks with 1D channels. When proceeding with solvothermal recrystallization in methanol, 1 gives complex 2, accompanied by structure transformation, and shows tilted interpenetrated 2D → 3D frameworks. When induced by different guest molecules for subtle modification of the local environments of the NiII centers, the complexes of 1 and 2 crystallize in different space groups. As a result, structure transformation from 1 to 2 leads to the modification of their magnetic properties and circular dichroism spectra. Furthermore, 1 and 2 can be used as heterogeneous catalysts in the Knoevenagel condensation with high catalytic activities. Investigations on their potential use as catalysts for other reactions are in progress.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture containing ptd (0.3 mmol), NiSO4·5H2O (0.5 mmol), and water (15 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, and 0.22 mL concentration 0.01 mol/L NaOH solution (pH = 10.1) was added and stirred for 30 min then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL), which was heated at 160 °C for 3 days and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h. Blue needle crystals of 1 were obtained, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 17% (based on NiII). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd: C,36.25; H, 3.83; N, 21.14. Found: C: 37.04; H: 3.21; N: 22.91. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3450(s), 1634(s), 1553(s), 1458­(m), 1460­(m), 1422­(m), 1364­(m), 1309(s), 1191­(m), 1097­(w), 1102­(w), 1054­(w), 1034­(w), 984­(m), 819­(w), 738­(m), 718­(m), 662(s), 612(s). The enantiomorphs (Λ-1 and Δ-1) with similar crystal shapes could be separated from the resulting mixed crystalline products of 1, on the basis of their slightly different cell determination (Table S1).

[Ni<sub>3</sub>(ptd)<sub>6</sub>]·10H<sub>2</sub>O·3.5MeOH (<bold>2</bold>, Including <bold>Λ-2</bold> and <bold>Δ-2</bold>)

As-synthesized 1 in methanol (10 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) was stirred in a Teflon-lined autoclave and placed under autogenous pressure at 130 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 2 were obtained in yields of about 19% (based on 1). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd: C, 38.89; H, 4.03; N, 21.14. Found: C, 39.15; H, 4.22; N, 21.94. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3445(s), 1632(s), 1551(s), 1460­(m), 1460­(m), 1421­(m), 1364­(m), 1309(s), 1191­(m), 1096­(w), 1102­(w), 1052­(w), 1034­(w), 984­(m), 819­(w), 738­(m), 720­(m), 662(s), 616(s).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

[Ni3(ptd)6]⋅15.5H2O (1, Including Λ-1 and Δ-1)

A mixture containing ptd (0.3 mmol), NiSO4⋅5H2O (0.5 mmol), and water (15 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, and 0.22 mL concentration 0.01 mol/L NaOH solution (pH = 10.1) was added and stirred for 30 min then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL), which was heated at 160 °C for 3 days and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/h. Blue needle crystals of 1 were obtained, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 17% (based on NiII). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd: C,36.25; H, 3.83; N, 21.14. Found: C: 37.04; H: 3.21; N: 22.91. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3450(s), 1634(s), 1553(s), 1458(m), 1460(m), 1422(m), 1364(m), 1309(s), 1191(m), 1097(w), 1102(w), 1054(w), 1034(w), 984(m), 819(w), 738(m), 718(m), 662(s), 612(s). The enantiomorphs (Λ-1 and Δ-1) with similar crystal shapes could be separated from the resulting mixed crystalline products of 1, on the basis of their slightly different cell determination (Table S1).

[Ni3(ptd)6]⋅10H2O⋅3.5MeOH (2, Including Λ-2 and Δ-2)

As-synthesized 1 in methanol (10 mL) and ethanol (1 mL) was stirred in a Teflon-lined autoclave and placed under autogenous pressure at 130 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 2 were obtained in yields of about 19% (based on 1). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd: C, 38.89; H, 4.03; N, 21.14. Found: C, 39.15; H, 4.22; N, 21.94. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3445(s), 1632(s), 1551(s), 1460(m), 1460(m), 1421(m), 1364(m), 1309(s), 1191(m), 1096(w), 1102(w), 1052(w), 1034(w), 984(m), 819(w), 738(m), 720(m), 662(s), 616(s).

metadata.title:
Spontaneous Resolution and Structure Transformation
of NiII Metal–Organic Frameworks from an Achiral
Precursor
